computer.description:
This is a French professional computer conceived by ADD-X Syst?mes based at Blagnac (Toulouse).
It was a CP/M, MP/M compatible system powered by a Z80, with 64k RAM. It had 2.4 MB on floppies but an optional 20 MB hard-disk could be added.
It was followed by the SMP-5 .
There were also two other models, the SM1 and SM2 which were quite similar technically (Z80, 64k RAM), but could be expanded to multipost configurations with up to 8 stations. The SM2 had a CII-HB D140 hard-disk (20 MB) built-in whereas the SM1 had only a 2 MB floppy-drive.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Complete system with a dual 1.2 MB 8" floppy disk drive unit and a Bull 'Minidisk' 20 MD hard disk unit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the numerous LEDs which inform the user of the actual state of the serial and parallel communications with the main unit and printer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SM1 REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><Font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Dip-switches for the terminal serial communication adjustments<br> <b><Font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Serial connector<br> <b><Font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b><Font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Floppy disk unit interface<br> <b><Font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Hard disk drive interface<br> <b><Font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Serial printer connectors<br> <b><Font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Parallel printer connectors<br> <b><Font color="blue">(8)</font></b> 7 workstation USART and com ports</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SM2 REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SM2 could manage up to 8 workstations.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE MAIN UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The logic cards are inserted on both sides of a back plane mounted vertically.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The workstation cards are mounted on the right side. Each card features a Z80 processor, 64 KB of RAM (32 x 4116 chips) and can manage 2 independent workstations.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>On the right-hand side one finds the main CPU card (the upper one), and four I/O cards in charge of the FDD, HDD, workstations, Parallel and Serial printer management.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CPU BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The CPU card (Z80 processor and 64 KB of RAM) is very like the workstation cards.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE FD UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8", 1.2 MB floppy disk drives came from Magnetic Peripherals, Inc., a subsidiary of Control Data.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BULL MINIDISK</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Bull 'Minidisk' (About 40 kg!) contains a 5" 20 MB fixed hard disk drive and a removable 10 MB cartridge drive.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE MINIDISK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Several Honeywell-Bull systems and other French manufacturers used this massive storage device which allowed easy backup of a 20 MB hard disk onto two removable 10 MB hard disk cartridges.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VIDEO TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The video terminal came from Facit, in Sweden. However, the logic board was made by the Tandy Corporation.</blockquote>
